prior_works.title: An Optimal Online Algorithm for Metrical Task Systems
prior_works.authors: Allan Borodin, Nathan Linial, Michael E. Saks
prior_works.role: Foundational model and bounds for MTS
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the MTS framework and tight competitiveness landscape (Θ(log n) randomized, Θ(n) deterministic), providing the benchmark that the paper preserves while compressing randomness and the single-agent lower bounds used to contrast with the collective setting.

prior_works.title: On Approximating Arbitrary Metrics by Tree Metrics
prior_works.role: Probabilistic tree embeddings enabling MTS algorithms
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced probabilistic embeddings of general metrics into trees, a key structural tool behind O(log n)-competitive randomized MTS algorithms whose competitiveness the present work preserves while drastically reducing random bits.

prior_works.title: A Tight Bound on Approximating Arbitrary Metrics by Tree Metrics
prior_works.authors: Jittat Fakcharoenphol, Satish Rao, Kunal Talwar
prior_works.role: Optimal HST embedding with O(log n) distortion
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided optimal tree-metric embeddings that underlie state-of-the-art randomized MTS algorithms on general metrics; combining such embeddings with the paper’s randomness compression yields the collective MTS O(log^2 n) guarantee.

prior_works.title: Probabilistic Computations: Toward a Unified Measure of Complexity
prior_works.role: Minimax principle connecting randomized algorithms and distributions over inputs
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Supplies the game-theoretic bridge used to reason about randomized online algorithms versus adversaries, enabling the reduction to small-support distributions that underpins the 2 log n-bit "barely random" transformation.

prior_works.title: Playing Large Games Using Simple Strategies
prior_works.authors: Richard J. Lipton, Evangelos Markakis, Aranyak Mehta
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows that near-optimal strategies in zero-sum games can be supported on only O(log N) samples, directly inspiring the construction of a distribution over at most n^2 random seeds that degrades competitiveness by only a constant factor.

prior_works.title: Private vs. Common Randomness in Communication Complexity
prior_works.role: Randomness reduction via small public coins
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates how long random strings can be replaced by O(log n) shared random bits with limited loss, a paradigm echoed in the paper’s conversion of fully randomized MTS algorithms into "barely random" ones with only a factor-2 penalty.

synthesis_narrative:
Cosson and Massoulié build on the classical MTS framework of Borodin, Linial, and Saks, which set the competitive-ratio targets—Θ(log n) randomized and Θ(n) deterministic—for general metrics. The algorithmic path to these targets typically relies on probabilistic metric embeddings: Bartal’s seminal randomized tree embeddings and the optimal Fakcharoenphol–Rao–Talwar (FRT) bound reduce general metrics to tree metrics with O(log n) distortion, enabling O(log n)-competitive randomized MTS strategies that constitute today’s gold standard.

The paper’s core innovation—compressing arbitrary fully randomized MTS algorithms to ones using only 2 log n random bits with just a constant (factor-2) loss—leans on game-theoretic and derandomization insights. Yao’s minimax principle recasts the adversarial interaction as a zero-sum game, permitting analysis in terms of mixed strategies. Lipton–Markakis–Mehta’s small-support theorem then guarantees near-optimality with distributions supported on only O(log N) samples, which the authors instantiate as a seed set of size about n^2, matching the 2 log n-bit claim. Conceptually akin to Newman’s public-coin reduction in communication complexity, this yields an order-optimal “barely random” algorithm whose randomness does not scale with the request sequence length.

Finally, combining the compressed randomness with metric embeddings explains the collective MTS result: running a team large enough to cover the small seed support recovers the expected randomized performance, and the FRT distortion compounds to deliver the stated O(log^2 n) competitiveness when k ≥ n^2.
